question: There's no mistake - you're sure?
answer: We've got five thousand cases now, Mr President. That's in three weeks. The number is doubling every hundred and sixty-eight hours. That's a geometric progression, sir. In three months there'Il be over seven million cases. After that we hit the wall - According to this, there won't be a live birth on the planet.

question: These are just computer projections -
answer: Tell that to the dinosaurs, sir. Six months and twenty-one days.

question: Can't somebody tell me - what exactly are we dealing with. Is it a virus or what?
answer: We don't know, sir.

question: Whatever they need, Bob - anything. Harry Truman put together the Manhattan Project - you understand? Of course we're going to have to manage itl We're going to have to manage a whole lot of things. But can't we take at least one moment to be human?
answer: Who is it?

question: Who is it?
answer: Will Robinson.

question: I think you have the wrong house.
answer: I work at the department. The Internet, Doctor. It's a highway - you can ride it anywhere you want. I got into 'the Center for Disease Control. I had a look at their raw data.

question: Jesus. Do you know what you're doing? This is the White House we're talking about.
answer: ) I've listened at the lab - I think I know where you're looking. Bacterias mostly, but there's a strong push into the retro-viruses. You're wrong, Doctor.

question: Really - and I thought I was arrogant. But then, I'm just a professor.
answer: No virus or bacteria has ever discriminated on the grounds of sex.

question: I can think of one.
answer: Sure, it can start in pockets but it never stays there. This thing does. It only affects women of child-bearing age. What - it's so smart it can recognize motherhood? I don't think so. No, this is into the very heart of what we are. This is genetic. This is part of the DNA.

question: Thank you. A hundred thousand genes make up human DNA - that really narrows it down.
answer: As a matter of fact it does. There's only one part of the DNA that's passed exclusively through women. Thirty-seven genes, the oldest part of the human organism - Over the years there's been speculation -not all of it crazy either - that somehow it triggers aging, He slides a sheaf of yellowing extracts from scientific journals across the table. She doesn't pay them any attention - she's thinking.

question: You realize what you're saying, don't you? A bacteria - I think we'd get it for sure. A virus -you'd have to say we've got a chance. But say you're right. The mitochondrial DNA - that's so far out on the frontier, we can barely see it.
answer: Like I said - it doesn't get any worse than this. Are you okay?

question: Sure.
answer: Shit. You're pregnant, aren't you?

question: I thought you'd like to know - we're looking at mitochondrial DNA,
answer: Thanks for telling me.

question: Is that you? Seattle. Is that where you went to school?
answer: No. Princeton.

question: Expensive.
answer: A scholarship. Then I did some post-graduate work... I never really finished. It's a Kestrel 24 - I haven't seen one of those in years. She's a beautiful boati

question: My grandfather left it to me. I don't sail it much any more - it's too hard to find a for'etd hand.
answer: What about your husband - doesn't he sail.

question: I don't know - I haven't met him yet. I wanted a baby but I'm thirty-four-years old. Sooner or later you realize that somewhere along the way you've missed the man you've been waiting for.
answer: What did you do - ask a friend?

question: I thought of it.
answer: Lucky friend.

question: I went to a clinic. Not exactly romantic, but it worked.
answer: How many people have you put on the mDNA?

question: Seven.
answer: That's all?!

question: That's all I can spare. It's just a theory -one of dozens of theories. What is it with you - it's not just science is it? Why are you so passionate about this?
answer: I know I'm right. It's a mutation. A hundred thousand years it's probably been lying there -shifting, weaving into the mDNA. You either go back and change evolution or you engineer it out. Seven peopleYou might as well shoot peas at a dam.

question: You haven't answered my question - why so passionate?
answer: The question's not relevant. The only thing I'm interested in is the science.

question: You want to tell me what's going on?
answer: Don't ask, Kris, I'd have to lie and I don't want to do that to my best friend,

question: The rumor is, you've done something really big. They say the Defense Department is taking it over. Okay, okay - I'm sorry I asked. So what about this guy - what's he done?
answer: He hasn't done anything - I'm just interested.

question: Ten thousand employment records I've got on file and you want to know about a lab assisant?
answer: The smartest assistant I've ever known.

question: What - he can mop and fart at the same time? He's handsome, at least I'll say -
answer: No, but he's the most unbelievable smelling man.

question: Smelling? You're pregnant - obviously your hormones have gone crazy. What exactly does he smell like?
answer: You know...

question: Of course he does - that's the Lysol. That's strange - there's supposed to be a background sheet. Family, school -all that shit. It must have gotten lost.
answer: Tell her to take a message.

question: What do they want?
answer: I think Washington's news management just went south.

question: This used to be the basement of the Psychology Department. We just sort of stacked everything around 'em - Flotation tanks. They used 'em for experiments in sensory degradation -
answer: Deprivation - sensory deprivation.

question: Yeah, well - whatever. Hey, fella - what are you doing?
answer: Just looking. I'll be coming back - I'll need a key. One other thing - don't tell anyone, huh?

question: Here's another one - "Mitochondrial DNAA Map to the Past."
answer: Who's it by?

question: Same guy - Doctor Robert Plant.
answer: Jesus, what did this guy do - write the book on it? Who is he?

question: Wow - I thought your career was impressive. Degrees in medicine and microbiology. A PhD at 24, a member of the Academy of Sciences, published twenty times by 1974...
answer: And then?

question: Then nothing.
answer: Where did he go as an undergraduate?

question: Princeton.
answer: On a scholarship? Robert! Doctor Plant! What about hie house?

question: You wanna tell me what exactly you're doing?
answer: Looking for a date.

question: What's wrong with a calendar?
answer: These are chemical sequences - they represent human genes. By following a trail of mutations, I can date them. I'm trying to find out when a major change occurred in something called the mitochondrial DNA.

question: The mitochondrial DNA? Yeah... well that makes sense. You've found it?
answer: Maybe...

question: So - what's the date?
answer: The best computer science can do? One hundred and two thousand years ago.

question: Sort of what I figured - give or take a day or two.
answer: This is someone's version of the prehistoric world. I'm interested in the geography, the atmosphere -that sort of stuff.

question: Where are we?
answer: Africa - that's where Mankind started.

question: I'll see you in the morning.
answer: Yeah. Thank you - for helping me, I mean.

question: It sounds like you're leaving or something.
answer: No. I just wanted to say it, that's all.

question: What exactly are you doing? You're a bit old to try and make your mark, aren't you? Anyway, nobody listens to people like us.
answer: Fate can be kind - sometimes a man gets a second chance. Do you know what it's like to be ridiculed, to have your ideas thrown back in your face? And that was the easy part. I guess that's what I'm doing - I want to prove that I was right.

question: You're lying to me.
answer: What do you mean?!

question: You are going somewhere. I don't know where it is. I'm not even sure I can imagine it. Good luck, though. I hope you find whatever it is you're looking for.
answer: Thanks.

question: You were right, Luc. That work you remembered from Berkeley - he was the one that did it. He said man was the last step on an evolutionary trail. Within every one of us is the history of our race. It's imprinted on our genes - like a map. Anyone that can find the chemical key can travel back down it. Through the womb. Through time and space - He was the best of his generation. He thinks so. He's got the genetic material for the key. All he needs are flotation tanks.
answer: A theory's one thing - do you really think he'll try it?

question: He's spent fifteen years as a lab assistant. He lives in a two room walk-up with a cat. No family, no friends. What's There's left for him here? Of course he'll do it. NO! If we open the hatch, I think we'll kill him. It's too late - it's his journey, he's going to have to take it. Everything's here - he kept a record of every step. He can even tell the date -forty hours after he arrives there's a solar eclipse.
answer: Billie - there's a note for you.

question: I don't have a tribe.
answer: No man can live without a tribe! How would he hunt the mighty animals? Who would keep his fire burning?

question: I come from far away... I'm a traveler.
answer: What is traveler? Is that a tribe? You carry things taken from our hunters! Kill him.

question: Show him to me. All my life I've dreaded this day.
answer: We've just spent an hour trying to save him -

question: Kill him!
answer: The animal's unique, my lord. At least we should look at his brain. Maybe it's possible to remove the frontal lobes without killing him. Imagine - a tame human!

question: Man can't be tamed. Alone among God's primates he kills for lust or greed. He will murder his own brother to possess his brother's land.
answer: The doctor's only asking for a chance to experiment. The benefits would be enormous. A tame species of human could double food production, at last we could dam the rivers.

question: You don't know what you're dealing with.
answer: It's just an animal, Ma-Gog.

question: So you lived, then?
answer: What did they do?

question: They gave you blood.
answer: I hope you had a medical. What is this place?

question: It was a slaughterhouse.
answer: For horses?

question: They use it for stables now. No - s different kind of animal. For humans. In my father's time, the apes rounded up tribes and brought them here. Young apes killed some during their manhood rites, the others were made sport of in the corrals. At the end, the bodies were thrown onto the belts and fed to the fire.
answer: Why haven't they killed you?

question: They keep me ss bait. My name is Aragorn - I am the Ranger of the Easterlings, the Leader of the Seven Tribes. They hope the warriors will come and try to free me.
answer: And will they?

question: Not if they fear my anger. I was taken in summer and now winter's almost gone. Even the apes grow tired - soon they'll make me walk the Paths of the Dead.
answer: what is it?

question: It's called the Crescent of Light - it's the talisman of my rank.
answer: Silver.

question: Mithral is how we name it..
answer: Can I borrow it?

question: Who are you? What brings you to the valley of the tribes?
answer: I meant you no harm. I'm looking for woman, one of my own kind. Do you know of people like me?

question: Never.
answer: If you want to get out of hare. I need the talisman. Aragorn.

question: What are you doing?
answer: Watch - they're going to bring in the dogs.

question: This doesn't seem like the way out.
answer: We're not going out - not yet.

question: So what are we doing? Killing?! Don't be stupid -
answer: You do what you like! But I'm the Ranger of the Easterlings -I won't leave here until it's done.

question: Thanks. I'll remember that.
answer: What are you doing?

question: Looking for the keys.
answer: No!

question: He saved our lives.
answer: He's an ape!

question: Luc?
answer: I'm sixty-two years old. I've seen us go from DC3s to landing on the moon. In my life I've won all the glittering prizes. I've always believed nothing was beyond the reach of Man, but I'll tell you honestly - this may never be unraveled. If it is, it won't be in my lifetime. So what do we do? I think it's like Gatsby -"so we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past." There's no other way, ia there?

question: Luc? Twelve weeks.
answer: Good night, Billie.

question: But the animal's not stupid - he knows come day-break we'll be tracking him. Who's to say he'll run for home?
answer: No - he's not stupid. But even dogs hunt in packs of seven. Every animal needs its kind. And when we find them - what then?

question: What do you think?!
answer: Just like the tribes - burn them out of their holes, put them to the sword? I don't mind doing that - I like it - but it's never enough, is it? No matter how many we kill, every year they're still here. Why will it be any different with the Blue Eyes? What we need is a final solution. Doctor Zora's brought back patients from a place called Kismatu. I've been talking to her about it -

question: He's their leader - he can never take his eye from the mountain. He has to do what he thinks is right. Don't judge him, Will. I couldn't have done it. I wonder if you could? One of those women he just killed wes his daughter.
answer: Fuck you, Strider! Tell me!

question: don't know if it's true.., my sister's mate works in the lab. He says Doctor Zora's working on some disease -
answer: What sort of disease?

question: Of the children, I think - ape children.
answer: How did they die, Strider? Old in the belly -is that how?!

question: Some of them. You know this disease? They haven't done it yet. It may not work.
answer: They will and it does.

question: That's funny - that's exactly what an ape would say. I'm sorry...
answer: What about you, Strider - why were you in the cell?

question: I fought another ape. Nothing very heroic, I'm afraid - I was drunk. He fell badly, his head hit the branch of a tree going down. It broke his neck.
answer: What's the punishment?

question: At the ceremony of summer rites, the high priest would curse me with death. You knew, didn't you? You knew the sun was going to swallow the moon. That's why you weren't afraid.
answer: Yes - I knew.

question: WHO ARE YOU, WILL?
answer: I've come a long way, Strider - it's farther then I can explain.

question: I've heard stories - old apes tell them 'round the fire late at night - of strange lands where the creatures can tell the future. Is that where you're from?
answer: In a way.. yeah, it's something like that.

question: So what happens to it afl, to the world we've built? Tell me that.
answer: It passes away.

question: History remembers, though - it's passed on, what we did, I mean?
answer: No, Strider - there's nothing, not a trace left behind.

question: So it's just vanity then - what we believe, that the works of the ape will last forever?
answer: Yes, it's vanity. But not just of apes, Strider -maybe of men, too.

question: Will! (indicates Strider Who's he?
answer: I'll explain later. What made you come? I thought the mDNA was just a theory. One of dozens of theories - isn't that what you said?

question: We did a lot of work. I guess I was wrong.
answer: People have been wrong about a lot of things. This is the rift valley in Kenya - That's Kilamanjaro - ten thousand feet higher but a hundred thousand years of wind and rain will turn it into the mountain we know. Think of it - we've come back a hundred thousand years! Everyone told me it couldn't be done, but we've crossed the frontier now - Man has traveled through space and time. How long has science dreamed of that?

question: How long have you?
answer: All my life.

question: An ape civilization? You said there was a city.., what happened to it all?
answer: You know what we've found of Aragorn's whole race? Seventeen bones, that's all. Anthropologists have discovered evidence of the apes - we call them skulls. Bones last a lot longer than civilizations.

question: I guess there's a lesson in that.
answer: Listen, Billie - the apes have discovered a disease. It's really rare and, lucky for them, it's in an isolated area. They're not stupid - they understand it's potential. They plan to give it to the tribes And maybe they do, but it doesn't matter -Aragorn's people aren't us. Already evolution's taken another track - Somewhere in the rift valley is someone like us - the first man.

question: Woman. You said it was in the mitochondrial DNA - it has to be a woman.
answer: You're right. Sooner or later the apes find her. She doesn't look like the tribes but the apes don't care - she's human.

question: After a hundred thousand years?
answer: The planet's five billion years old. What's that to Nature? A blink of the eye. That's the theory, anyway.

question: There's not much time, Will. We have to find her before the apes and we have to do it within four weeks.
answer: Jesus, Billie! Four weeks? We've got a theory - that's all. We don't even know half the problems we're dealing with. You can't put a deadline on science.

question: Science, Will? What about people? Isn't that what this is all about. I'm sorry - I thought there were children dying.
answer: Sure. Of course it's about that too.

question: But then, you don't care muchabout people do you?
answer: No - I guess I don't. Not for a long time. Ideas and knowledge are what matter. They're the shining ideals. That's the only way we progress.

question: Progress to what? We're both children of our age, aren't we? We've grown up to believe the more we know, the more advanced we are. But what does that mean if we've forgotten the things of real value. You know the reason I came? It's got nothing to do with science or knowledge. I'm going to have a child -that's why I'm here. Uke you said, the women's out there somewhere. Why ere we traveling with them?
answer: We wouldn't last a day. We've got to keep moving, Billie. The apes are like storm-troopers.

question: Where are they now?
answer: Right behind. I think Strider has some sort of tribal intuition. He says he can hear their hoof beats in his head.

question: You carry part of my spirit with you -I owe you my life. Welcome, Traveler.
answer: Are the seven tribes here?

question: All except the Antelope. They hunt the plains far to the west - they have the longest journey.
answer: Will they come?

question: Who knows - maybe the apes have found them. Nobody has seen them for many summers gone. Why?
answer: I'm searching for someone - a young woman. She looks like us ...

question: Is she a relative - was she born to your hearth?
answer: To all of our hearths. My race reveres her. We think of her as the first woman. Without her. our lives are nothing. Have you seen her? You're sure? Perhaps some of the women have seen something?

question: She looks like you, you say? No offense, Traveler, but the women say you're the ugliest man they've ever seen. A woman that looks like you - I'm sure they would have talked about it.
answer: Ugly?

question: I'm sorry I can't help.
answer: We've traveled without rest - there are soldiers a day behind. The ape says it's an army.

question: And there are more coming from the north. Five squadrons et least, the runners say. It's led by the old warrior Nazgul.
answer: Is that why you called the gathering?

question: Great things are moving, Ranger - We either fight or flee - the Tribes must decide.
answer: I know you, Kip - you always were a fighter. What do the others say? I'll walk the path Mother Earth has laid for me, but I'll walk it no more as Ranger. A man leads from his heart and winter has come early to mine. If I should have had a son, I would have hoped for a man as fine as you. This is my last act as Ranger of the Easterlings- Take care of my father's people. Guide them well.

question: They think if they leave the valley, their totems won't follow. Without them, they say they're dead anyway.
answer: We should go now. Oh, nol We're not fighting someone else's war -

question: Listen to me -
answer: We've got four weeks, Willl Four weeks to find her. She's not here, so whet are we waiting for? Let's go!

question: Listen, Billie! We know the future - but if we beat the apes, they can't harm the woman.
answer: Beat the apes?! And say we don't - or say one of us gets captured. What then? Don't you understand? Four weeksi

question: Yeah, I understand - but those things aren't going to happen. We know things the apes can't even dream of. This is our world, Billie - men won it with their minds. All we need is knowledge and science. We've got them both. We can win!
answer: What are we going to do - dazzle them with calculus? This is an army, Will - you said it yourself. Storm-trooperst

question: Look - Taste it. That's saltpeter - the natural form of potassium nitrate. The caves are littered with the stuff. You've smelt the air - there's sulfur all around. If we burn timber, that'Il give us charcoal. You're s scientist - you know what it means.
answer: It's strange, isn't it? Give s man s problem and the first thing he thinks about is weapons.

question: We're a frail species, Billea. It's only weapons that have made us bigger than we are.
answer: Or smaller.

question: Some times when we want something so bad, we can take a thing and twist it in our head. You're sure about this, Billie?
answer: I'm pregnant, Will - I'm not crazy. She's not like them - she's a mutation. Evolution's always trying to improve on itself. It's turned out a child that can walk taller and run faster, one whose brain-pan holds a mind that can think laterally. I've seen her, Will. I've held her in my arms - she was us.

question: You said she was with Drak.
answer: On a chain.

question: It's two days' march to the city. Was she wounded - can she make it?
answer: She can make it.

question: No!
answer: Of course we can't...

question: We call it a city - it's more like a fortress, Billie. It can't be done.
answer: The three of you got out - everyone thought that was impossible too.

question: We were lucky. But that's the trouble with luck - it runs out. I don't want to be back in the city when it does.
answer: What about Eve - what do we do, just forget about her?

question: No. Maybe we can't stop the apes giving her the disease - but they'll have to turn her loose. That's the only way she can infect others. So we lay a plan and we find her. Then it's our job to stop her having children. If we can do that, it can't be passed on through the race.
answer: How long will that take - less than twenty-five days ?

question: No. We can't take our eye off the goal. If we solve this, you can have other children. Not if wa throw our lives away, though.
answer: Whose, Will - whose children?

question: guess that's your call.
answer: What sort of father would you make? You told me once the only thing that matters is knowledge. That's wrong. Science and technology can only take you so far - in the end it's our humanity that maners. That's what makes us great. You're a wonderful scientist, Will -but what sort of person are you? What would you do if it was your child?

question: We'll both die. Let gol Will shakes his head - no. Hanging on to the rope one-handed, the current tearing at his body, he tries to haul Strider in. Another minute, we'll both be dead. Do it, Willl If nothing else, I made it to the Falls No Return.
answer: The sacred words, Strider - what are the words?!

question: "In the beginning...
answer: 'In the beginning was the word and the word wes God...' You'll walk in the next world, Strider.

question: How do you know?
answer: I've seen the future, haven't I?

question: Good-bye Will. Take care of Billie.
answer: And the word was God. Yea, though I walk through the valley of death, I will fear no evil... Surely goodness and mercy shall follow me all the days of my life and I will dwell in the house of the Lord forever. Amen.

question: We thought you were dead.
answer: Hunted, but not dead. A dozen of us were driven back in the battle - For three days a squadron of apes have tracked us. Last night we ambushed them. We're heading now for the eagle's nest.

question: We're all that's left of the Seven Tribes.
answer: But nothing's the same now. Think of the women-folk. What will become of them?

question: You can't go on, Will - not like this.
answer: What about the baby?

question: I'll keep going - I'll try and get Eve.
answer: Alone? Don't be ridiculous -

question: Look at you - you can barely walk.
answer: If I can just get up - help me. Don't do this to me - pleasel

question: You've done enough - more than anyone else could. You're one of the finest men
answer: Billie!She's almost through the tangled roots. I made a mistake once - I went on a journey with someone I loved. At the end, I let her go into danger alone.

question: Where was that - Berkeley, Will? What happened?
answer: I knew I'd found the chemical key. I was working with three young researchers. One of them was a woman called Ali Conoily. We were engaged. They were the ones that went into the tanks. I didn't know as much as I thought I did. They died in there.

question: Why didn't you go, Will?
answer: We all wanted to. It was a great adventure. Wa drew lots for it. I should never have agreed, but we were young - and like the young we thought life would last forever.

question: Robert Plant died too, didn't he - in a way?
answer: The experiment was unauthorized. There was an inquiry. They said the theory had no basis. 'Ludicrous" was a word they used. My career had gone up like a rocket. It came down like the stick. I couldn't find work anywhere

question: "Will Robinson" - that was your joke, I guess. You were Lost in Space, were you?
answer: Yeah, but I never realized it'd be so appropriate. had twenty years to work out where my research went wrong - so what, though. It was just a mind game. But I've learnt a lot of things - the most important is that sometimes you get a second chance. A second chance for a lot of things - And when you do, you have to grab it and make sure you never let it go. I've got the heart, Billie. It's my body that's failing me.
